Posts.Content: Hi Becci, I have had two sessions of EC and am having my third on Friday. I have used the cold cap and actually found it quite pleasant! The onco nurse said that it is usually older people who have trouble tolerating it. My hair has thinned a bit, and there are little patches of very fine hair above my ears, but it is no more noticeable than someone with fine hair. I have a defined straight fringe and the thinning is most noticeable at the parting so I think a lot depends on your hairstyle. On sunny days I tend to have sunglasses on my head which disguises the line. I don't know how long I will keep my hair but trying is making me feel like I am doing something! I'd say give it a go and if you don't like it you can take it off. Best of luck x
Posts.Title: Starting EC and advice on scalp cooling please!!!

Posts.Content: Hi, Love your positive end to your message!!!! I have had 4 EC which I believe is pretty much the same as FEC as the E is the evil one. I had to call emergency oncology because of the pain of tongue ulcers but after the first round I was fine. The doc prescribed co codamol, which helped, but after the first session it never hurt as much. Have difflam mouthwash prescribed and that really helps. I had a really bad twitchy face side effect due to the anti emitics but didn't realise that what caused it. if you have any side effects then tell them straight away  as i suffered for weeks for n o reason. EC makes you very tired for a week after and suffering a weird jet lag experience.  tax has been a breeze in comparison. Best of luck! x
Posts.Title: FEC and sore veins

Posts.Content: waaaahhhh! going slightly bonkerswith new fangled tablet  thing, but I just wanted to say that having been through cancer was a really positive experience. I find this quite difficult to say but having cancer has made my life better in so many ways. I have become a positive person xx
Posts.Title: Happy and you know it...

Posts.Content: Great to hear that! I have too. I now feel privileged  to be here and see every day as one I didn't expect to have xxx O !..S O G
Posts.Title: Happy and you know it...

Posts.Content: Hi Heather,   Thank you for your lovely response and I hope your experiece  is as good as mine. Cancer is something that happens to us but we should in no way be defined by it! Lots of lovexx
Posts.Title: Happy and you know it...

Posts.Content: Thank you, mine was grade 3. I had 8 round of chemo ,which shrunk it to lumpercomy proportions, then radio. Mum is 77 so they are not sure whether she needs chemo or whether it is 'worth it'', their words, not mine! It seems that they don't really care about older ladies x
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Hi, It';s been a while since I posted but my mum has just been diagnosed too. She is a trouper and taking it as well as she can. her hospital haven't given her a grade yet as they said they would have to wait until after surgery to do so. I am a bit concerned about this as I was given mine straight away (the wonderful Guy;s in london) is this normal? I am obviously also concerned about any hereditary issues, mine was HER2 positive and from what I have read there seems to be a bit ambiguity on whether it is genetric or not. Any ideas anyone? x
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Brilliant!!!! I have been trained to put out food on the shed every evening by the familiar WAAAAH! WAAAAH! WAAAAH call. xx
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Aw, thank you so much. I feel awful because I am so far away from her. I live in Brighton and she is near Edinburgh. I went to her appointment when she got the news and will be back up a couple of days after the op. My two sisters are there but I just feel so bloody helpless! I am making sure I am there for significant appointments but feel so useless. xx
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Thanks Ali, I am just feeling grateful that I had it 1st so know what to ask. xx
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Mum is having mastectomy on wed, no rads planned but possibly chemo. Hopefully she will be ok but not sure why they are saying no rads but possibly chemo x
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Thanks Judith. Haven't made it to the beach much this year but am loving my baby seagulls who are driving everyone else mad! Given the amount of ladies in the family I am a bit concerned about any heriditary bits, can anyone shed light on this? x
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Thanks, that does help. I think my first reaction was one of panic due to the amount of women in the family. My cousin had it too so it is easy to think the worst. Fingers crossed she will be ok. x
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Thank you x
Posts.Title: forth valley hospital larbert

Posts.Content: Hello Please can anyone explain this to me as can't ring the cancer nurse til Mon. I have a 5cm tumour in my left breast and its in left lymph nodes rhs definitely dcis not found in nodes yet but will have sentinel node biopsy during double mastectomy. I have had CT scan so know it hasn't spread further Anyhoo surgeon + chemo Dr keep talking about me having stage 1 cancer and whenever I google because of size of tumour + lymph nodes looks to me like stage 3? But apparently they grade by tmn - which still doesn't add up Anyway light shed much appreciated xxx
Posts.Title: stage/ tiering system confusion

Posts.Content: Hi, I have been through breast cancer and now my mum has it. I was treated at Guy's and mum is at Forth Valley. Has anyone else been to Forth Valley and, if so, how did you find it? i can't find any info about the oncologists on line xx
Posts.Title: forth valley hospital larbert

Posts.Content: Hi Bev, I was allowed to keep my bottom half on and quickly worked out easy access outfits! The radio takes about two mins, it is the position adjusting that takes time xx
Posts.Title: Markers

Posts.Content: Hi Bev, I was allowed to keep my bottom half on and quickly worked out easy access outfits! The radio takes about two mins, it is the position adjusting that takes time xx
Posts.Title: Markers

Posts.Content: Hello Was just wondering if anyone had any advice went to chemo consent clinic yesterday initially given start date Mon then they realised I need a Hickman line due to double mastectomy lymph node clearance on right and sentinel node biopsy on right confirming lymph node involvement. Am so cross and looking faith in my oncologist who should have spotted need for line after getting histology. Heard the Secretary laughing down the phone at the idea of me getting a date anytime soon saying she had finally managed to get another patient booked in for 2/11.  Any ideas how to speed things up hate the idea of the cancer still being allowed to grow whilst the hospital mess things up Thanks
Posts.Title: Chemo delayed hickman line

Posts.Content: hi, a very lovely friend of mine bought me an Elizabeth Arden eyelash serum. I don't know if it was just coincidence but it seemed to work and my eyelashes reappeared. i can't remember what it was called but it comes in a little black velvet pouch. Just think of the money you are saving on waxing the other bits... x
Posts.Title: Eyebrows

Posts.Content: Thanks , have just crawled back into my cave for a rest...I'll check with the onco as the twitching is making me feel a bit self concious. There were three different anti emetics but haven't got the names with me. I had to take a few days off work this cycle with exhaustion so know will factor that in for the next session.  Only 2 more EC and 4 Tax to go...
Posts.Title: Which days are the most vulnerable.

Posts.Content: Hi, Sorry if this has come up before but I have been feeling awful on the day after stop taking the anti emetics. I get a twitchy face and feel like I have jetlag. I am on EC and have just had the second treatment and the same thing has happened. Is this normal? x
Posts.Title: Which days are the most vulnerable.

Posts.Content: Hello there happy new year!  After my first session of EC chemo I had a very bad reaction to the steroids. I ended up admitted to a ward for 10 days because I had very high blood pressure and a very low white blood cell count otherwise I'm sure it would've been the psych ward I thought my mum was the devil, I had solved Isis but as a result my husband would lock me in the hospital room and beat me up for 6 weeks, I had agreed to be the sadest girl in the world in exchange for my son being father Christmas...it was dreadful for me and those around me and I am only just back to normal. I have had 2 more rounds of EC without steroids the latest one made me feel very sick but I was only sick 2 days. The original plan was to now have 3 sessions of doxitaxel sp? However they cant give that without steroids so my consultant is talking to my mental health worker to agree what is best. I'm so scared of not getting the strong chemo I need and dying or having the strong chemo and waking up with my life in tatters again (it really was horrific) any advice would be much appreciated .  Emily xx
Posts.Title: Psychotic reaction to chemo steroids

Posts.Content: Hi, Just wondered whether anyone else had experienced this? It started at cycle 8, then i had a nasty crustry prone to bleeding nose and now happened again. I ended up with a bloody top lip on my last cycle, which is always quite embarrasing1 x
Posts.Title: Bloody nose on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi, I had 4 Ec, 4 TaX, surgery, 4 and a half weeks of radiotherapy and am now only on Herceptin (it started with the Tax in December). I am still having achey joints and chronic fatigue. My oncologist said the achey joints should be getting better by now. Has anyone else experienced achey joints after this length of time. I am starting to feel like a fraud! xx
Posts.Title: achey legs and fatigue on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Thanks Wendy, I just hoped it would go away and I could be normal! . I an mainly self employed so work silly hours, but just want to feel it will get better. I worked all the way through my treatment and am very annoyed to be so tired> i am also about 2 stone more than normal due to steroids, no excercise etc. How are you coping? xx tThanks for your support. xx
Posts.Title: achey legs and fatigue on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, What drugs are you having and are you having them  in UK or Oz? They are all different and affect people differently but would be interested to hear if oz treat things differently.  xxxx
Posts.Title: achey legs and fatigue on Herceptin

Posts.Content: I am being treated at Guy's in London which is a fantastic hospital. I chose to go there as had very little faith in my own hospital after being told " oh, it looks fine, I don't think there is anything to worry about". this was the second time I'd gone with a lump in the same place. I was told I had lumpy breasts the first time. It turned out to be a massive grade 3 cancer after they finally did further tests. I only have to travel about an hour and cannot fault the care I have had. I am very glad to hear that you and your sister in law are being looked after properly. Care n the UK is a bit of a postcode lottery and most people are unaware that they can elect to be treated at any hospital they choose. I was very lucky that a friend's mother told me this when I was diagnosed. x
Posts.Title: achey legs and fatigue on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Guys, Thank you so much for the reply> I an having Herceptin rather than the other drugs. I just feel so bl***dy old!. After a car journey I can barely get out of the car. I an mainly self employed so work silly hours, but just want to feel it will get better! Thanks for your support. xx
Posts.Title: achey legs and fatigue on Herceptin
